title: Lingerie Fonts
content:
Last time while reading a magazine, I saw on the back page a lingerie ad, that contained 2 fonts I wish to identify or at least find similar ones.

The fonts I'm looking for are  
- the one from the logo : Triumph  
- and the one in which the sentence "L'armature qui se fait oublier" is written.

Thanks for helping me out !

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20141203200347im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Triumph-2_4947.jpg)
author: Kaedi

comments.content:
As Ryuk says, the scripts are bespoke. Here are some monoline substitutes for \_L'armature qui se fait oublier\_. Hand Cursive

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20141203200347im_/http:/typophile.com/files/HandCursiveInUse_3649.gif)
  [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/okaycat/hand-cursive/](http://web.archive.org/web/20141203200347/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/okaycat/hand-cursive/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/okaycat/hand-cursive/")  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20141203200347im_/http:/typophile.com/files/TrueNorthScriptInUse_6128.gif)
  [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/cultivated-mind/true-north/](http://web.archive.org/web/20141203200347/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/cultivated-mind/true-north/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/cultivated-mind/true-north/")  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20141203200347im_/http:/typophile.com/files/SparkleScriptInUse_3802.gif)
  [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/keightley-ryan/sparkle-script/](http://web.archive.org/web/20141203200347/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/keightley-ryan/sparkle-script/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/keightley-ryan/sparkle-script/")  
Don

\_Triumph\_, also bespoke, is difficult to replace with a substitute. It seems to be based on the traditional 18th and 19th centuries English script but with a reduced inclination.  
For example Bo Berndal's Carl Beck

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20141203200347im_/http:/typophile.com/files/CarlBeckInUse_5416.jpg)
  
 [http://www.fonts.com/font/monotype/carl-beck/regular?SiteId=15](http://web.archive.org/web/20141203200347/http:/www.fonts.com/font/monotype/carl-beck/regular?SiteId=15 "http://www.fonts.com/font/monotype/carl-beck/regular?SiteId=15")  
Another script that attempted this is Aldo Novarese's Juliet, which has been digitized by Rebecca Alaccari and Patrick Griffin as Ambassador Script 
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20141203200347im_/http:/typophile.com/files/AmbassadorScriptInUse_3698.gif)
  [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/canadatype/ambassador-script/](http://web.archive.org/web/20141203200347/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/canadatype/ambassador-script/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/canadatype/ambassador-script/")  
Don

Here is some more of "Triumph Tailoress Script" as used at the Triumph website:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20141203200347im_/http:/typophile.com/files/TriumphTailoressScriptInUse_6666.jpg)
 Perhaps the additional letters will assist in finding a closer substitute.  
None of the suggestions so far really catch the flavor of this script.  
Don

Adding an interesting and beautifully crafted script as alternative for the main woodmark: [Feather Script](http://web.archive.org/web/20141203200347/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/lettering-inc/feather-script). The buckled/ribbon /T is even here and ready-to-go.

Feather Script is an unusual combination of an classic structured lowercase similar to Englische Schreibschrift with casual swooping capitals. Feather Script seems to give some hint as to how letters other than the \_T\_ in \_Triumph\_ could work with the \_Triumph\_ lowercase.  
As for the second script -- Triumph Tailoress Script -- it's a far from casual design. I made a somewhat similar \_f\_ from scratch.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20141203200347im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Recreated_t__6046.jpg)
  
The exercise was surprisingly time consuming. Wish I could find a similar design as elegant and structured in an an existing font that is available to the public.  
Don
